author: Yuji Nakamura
title: Japan Stocks Rise as Weaker Yen, Oil Boost Exporters, Shippers
text:
Japanese stocks rose as a weaker yen sent exporters higher and cheaper oil boosted airlines and shippers.
The Topix index climbed 0.5 percent to 1,670.70 as of 9:02 a.m. in Tokyo, after rising 5 percent last week, its best weekly performance since October. Markets were closed Monday for a holiday. The Nikkei 225 Stock Average added 0.5 percent to 20,744.85. The yen traded at 124.32 per dollar, near a six-week low. Crude oil held losses after dropping below $50 a barrel for the first time since April.
“The weaker yen and cheaper oil will have a positive effect on Japanese stocks,” Toshihiko Matsuno, chief strategist at SMBC Friend Securities Co. in Tokyo, said by phone. “Cheaper oil prices have led to lackluster moves in commodity-related shares in the global market, but cheaper commodities have come in tandem with a stronger dollar.”
The outlook for resources has soured as investors refocus on U.S. monetary policy, with bets that the Federal Reserve is moving closer to boosting interest rates fueling a resurgence in the dollar.
Futures on the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index slipped less than 0.1 percent. The underlying equity measure was little changed Monday, after briefly climbing above its previous closing record, as better-than-forecast corporate results offset a slump in commodities producers.
